concepts.title: Rational Numbers
concepts.content: A rational number is a number of the form m/n where m is any integer and n is any non-zero integer. Rational numbers include all natural numbers, integers, fractions and negative fractions. For example, 4 = 4/1, -3 = -3/1, 0 = 0/2 are all rational numbers.
keyPoints: Rational number: form m/n where m,n are integers, n‚â†0
All natural numbers, integers are rational numbers
Fractions like 1/2, 3/7, -17/28 are rational
0 = 0/1 is a rational number
Decimals like 2.17 = 217/100 are rational
concepts.funFact: üí° The word 'rational' comes from 'ratio' ‚Äî a rational number is a ratio of two integers!

concepts.title: Operations and Closure Property
concepts.content: The group of rational numbers is closed for all four operations ‚Äî addition, subtraction, multiplication and division (except division by zero). Unlike natural numbers (not closed for subtraction/division) and integers (not closed for division), rational numbers can always give a rational result.
keyPoints: Natural numbers: closed for + and √ó only
Integers: closed for +, -, √ó but NOT √∑
Rational numbers: closed for +, -, √ó, √∑ (not by zero)
Rational √∑ Rational (non-zero) = always Rational
Cannot divide any number by zero
concepts.funFact: üåê Rational numbers form a 'field' in mathematics ‚Äî the only type of numbers that are closed for all four basic operations!
concepts.textbookRef: Page 35: Closure Property of Rational Numbers

concepts.title: Multiplicative Inverse
concepts.content: To divide by a rational number, multiply by its multiplicative inverse. The multiplicative inverse of p/q is q/p. Their product equals 1. For negative fractions: -5/4 and -4/5 are multiplicative inverses. Note: -9/11 and -11/9 have product -1, so they are NOT multiplicative inverses.

examples.text: Multiplicative inverse of 7 is 1/7; of -7 is -1/7

keyPoints: Multiplicative inverse of p/q is q/p
Product of a number and its inverse = 1
For negative fractions: inverse of -a/b is -b/a
Division = multiply by multiplicative inverse
A number and its additive inverse are different from multiplicative inverse
concepts.funFact: üéØ The multiplicative inverse is also called the 'reciprocal' ‚Äî it flips the fraction upside down!

concepts.title: Rational Numbers Between Two Numbers
concepts.content: There are infinitely many rational numbers between any two rational numbers. To find numbers between 1/2 and 3/5: convert to common denominators (5/10 and 6/10), then multiply top and bottom to find more: 50/100 and 60/100, giving 51/100, 52/100, ... 59/100 between them.

examples.text: Between 1/2 and 3/5: convert to 7/14 and 8/14; midpoint = 15/28
Between 5/10 and 6/10: multiply by 10 ‚Üí 50/100 to 60/100, giving 9 more numbers
Between integers: integers are countable, but rationals between them are infinite
Midpoint of two rationals = (a+b)/2 is always a rational between them

keyPoints: There are infinitely many rationals between any two rationals
Method: convert to common denominators, then expand
Midpoint of a and b = (a+b)/2
Unlike integers: no 'next' rational number exists
We can always find more by using larger denominators
concepts.funFact: ‚ôæÔ∏è Between any two rational numbers, no matter how close, there are infinitely many more rational numbers ‚Äî this is called 'density'!

concepts.title: Decimal Forms and BODMAS
concepts.content: Rational numbers have either terminating decimals (division ends, e.g. 7/4 = 1.75) or recurring decimals (digit/group repeats, e.g. 5/3 = 1.666... = 1.6ÃÑ). BODMAS rule for simplification: Brackets first, then multiplication/division left to right, then addition/subtraction.
keyPoints: Terminating decimal: remainder becomes zero
Recurring decimal: digit or group repeats endlessly
Recurring shown with dot above digit or bar above group
BODMAS: Brackets, Of, Division, Multiplication, Addition, Subtraction
Multiplication and division: left to right; then addition and subtraction
concepts.funFact: üìê The fraction 22/7 is NOT exactly œÄ ‚Äî it equals 3.142857... (recurring), showing œÄ is irrational!

longAnswers.question: Explain why we take LCM of denominators while adding rational numbers.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Rational numbers can be added only when they have equal-sized parts (same denominator). Taking LCM gives the smallest common denominator, so each fraction is converted to equivalent fractions with equal parts. Then numerators are added and denominator remains common.
keyPoints: Convert to like denominators before addition/subtraction.
Use least common denominator (LCM) for efficiency.
Common mistake: adding denominators directly.

longAnswers.question: Find: 3/4 + (‚àí5/6).
longAnswers.modelAnswer: LCM of 4 and 6 is 12. Convert: 3/4 = 9/12, ‚àí5/6 = ‚àí10/12. Add numerators: 9 + (‚àí10) = ‚àí1. So result = ‚àí1/12.
keyPoints: Find LCM of denominators first.
Add signed numerators carefully.
Common mistake: ignoring negative sign of second fraction.

longAnswers.question: Evaluate: (‚àí7/9) √ó (18/21). Simplify.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: (‚àí7/9)√ó(18/21). Cancel common factors: 18/9=2 and 21/7=3. So result = ‚àí(1√ó2)/(1√ó3)=‚àí2/3.
keyPoints: Cross-cancellation simplifies multiplication.
Sign rule: negative √ó positive = negative.
Common mistake: canceling terms after addition/subtraction (allowed only in multiplication/division).

longAnswers.question: Compute: (5/8) √∑ (‚àí15/16).
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Division by a fraction means multiply by reciprocal. (5/8) √∑ (‚àí15/16) = (5/8)√ó(16/‚àí15). Cancel: 16/8=2, 5/15=1/3. Result = (1√ó2)/(1√ó‚àí3)=‚àí2/3.
keyPoints: a/b √∑ c/d = a/b √ó d/c.
Take reciprocal of divisor only.
Common mistake: not flipping the second fraction.
